title: Friday, 19th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

So, hi. Hello. Good morning.

PM11:03am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:03am

Apols for the slight delay

11:03 am
PM11:03am

You know Bryce, I need a break

PM11:03am

I might take the next month off

BE11:03am

K.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Yeah, I'm taking the next month off

PM11:04am

Today will be my last session to later in June

PM11:04am

You can bloody handle it

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Yep. That's fine. I bloody can.

PM11:04am

Actually, if/when I fell under a bus, how would you replace me?

PM11:04am

Or would you not bother?

11:05 am
BE11:05am

I'd hope AI had developed sufficiently to automise you by then.

BE11:05am

Though it might also have automised the bus under which you fell.

PM11:05am

hehe

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Which'd be an irony of sorts. A very small version of the machines taking over. To type stuff. About markets.

BE11:07am

Sometimes about markets anyway.

BE11:07am

Speaking of, should we do that? The markets typing stuff? For old times' sake?

11:07 am
PM11:07am

That said, if/when i fall under a bus or randomly take a month off, I'd miss the news

PM11:07am

So yes, markets

PM11:08am

But Assange???

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Corzine???

PM11:08am

wt whatever

PM11:08am

London’s Metropolitan Police issued a statement saying it was “obliged” to execute an arrest warrant issued in 2012 by Westminster Magistrate’s Court after WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange failed to surrender to authorities.

Still, the Met indicated it was prepared to consider the case as low priority given Sweden had dropped rape charges against him.

“The [Met] response reflected the serious nature of [the] crime,” the police said in their statement. “Now that the situation has changed and the Swedish authorities have discontinued their investigation into that matter, Mr Assange remains wanted for a much less serious offence. The [Met] will provide a level of resourcing which is proportionate to that offence.”

11:08 am
PM11:08am

And Corzine https://www.nytime...comeback.html?_r=0

PM11:09am

What is it with this guy?

PM11:09am

I'm not even sure how he escaped prosecution

11:09 am
BE11:09am

.............. I don't know. I'm not an expert on Swedish law, unlike 95% of the people on Twitter.

PM11:10am

I meant Corzine, not Assange

PM11:10am

But whatever

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Oh. Ditto American law, frankly. Actually, "law" would be a fair summary.

PM11:11am

(cleverhedge -- yes, Camp AV cancelled. Not a Nikkei decision. Closer to home...)

undefined
11:11 am
PM11:11am

So... a cautious recovery...

BE11:12am

It's a bit dull up the top end of the market, really. Slight rally from yesterday.

BE11:12am

(Which was largely ex divs plus sterling, but that didn't seem to stop everyone talking about Trump.)

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Heading below the waterline, there are any number of mentions on the right of Revolution Bars.

Revolution Bars Group PLC (RBG:LSE): Last: 134.53, down 69.47 (-34.05%), High: 163.00, Low: 134.05, Volume: 1.90m
BE11:13am

Which delivers a profit warning a day after it had a slightly peculiar shunt lower.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Albeit, as we said yesterday, on very little volume.

PM11:14am

There's got to be a stewards there

BE11:14am

Really?! I'd say not.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

??

BE11:14am

I mean, perhaps someone got wind that trading was bad.

PM11:15am

It moved 8 per cent, no?

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Yup. And perhaps they sold on that information, taking a price rather lower than the middle quote because that's how it works when you hold illiquid stocks.

PM11:15am

yeah yeah

BE11:15am

Is that worth a stewards? Are we really wanting to investigate every shrewd price move?

11:15 am
PM11:16am

Censored

BE11:17am

I mean! I'm all for efficient markets, in theory. But in a thin market the uneven distribution of information can cause a bit of extra volatility.

BE11:18am

The FCA has better things to be worrying about than someone perhaps hearing that trading wasn't great at a bars operator and choosing to sell. That's entirely innocuous behaviour unless proven otherwise, and I don't see a pressing need to prove it was otherwise.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Anyway.

BE11:18am

In terms of the warning ...........

BE11:18am

Here comes Peel Hunt.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Although LFL sales have remained good, at 1.7%, and gross
margins have strengthened slightly, the company’s previous
guidance has not properly reflected cost headwinds. As a result
of this and new openings taking longer to reach target profits, we
are downgrading our 2017E PBT forecast by 22%. Even after
this, the 6.5x EV/EBITDA valuation is not strenuous, but there
is unlikely to be a positive catalyst until new sites drive up
EBITDA (in H2 2018E).

BE11:19am

• LFL sales have remained good. The 1.7% increase over the last 10 months is above the sector average (the Coffer Peach Business Tracker rose by 1.1% over the same period). This has been achieved with no dilution in the gross margin.
• Costs bombshell. Despite growing the EBITDA margin by 12bps in H1, the company’s new guidance for flat EBITDA in 2017E implies a margin decline of 300bps in H2.
• Why? Management claims this is due to labour cost inflation and business rates even though this impact should not be a surprise, and is being managed by other operators (numerous Leisure companies have reported this week, without requiring forecast downgrades). We believe losing two CFOs in a relatively short period of time has not been helpful to RBG in this case.
• Management expects the adverse impact on 2018E to be lower due to new sites maturing, cost savings from workforce management systems and price increases. However, we are not assuming much benefit from cost reductions and price increases in our 2018E figures, which we have downgraded by 17% at PBT level.
• It is important that the company’s expansion plans remain in place, given that the company has a net cash position and a track record for generating a 38% cash ROI. The company intends to open six new bars in 2018E, which, together with the maturing of 2017E five openings, should drive EBITDA growth next year

BE11:20am

Even after today’s forecast downgrades, the shares are valued at 6.5x based on a share price of 204p. The opening price of 144p values the shares on 4.5x, which is below what one would expect an unbranded nightclub business to be valued on. We would buy the shares on current weakness, ahead of expansion-driven growth in 2018E.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

4.5 times. Cripes.

BE11:20am

There's no money in liquor.

BE11:20am

Have Numis as well.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

For FY17 we now assume lfl sales growth of 1.5%, GM reduction
of 100bp and 5% wage growth. This gives adjusted EBITDA (excluding pre-opening costs) of £15.6m, a 12% downgrade. EPS exc pre-opening cost is 13.7p (or 12.1p post). In FY18, lfl sales growth of c.3% will be needed to cover cost inflation in the existing estate. We cautiously assume 1.5% lfl sales growth but expect the group to generate c.£1m in cost mitigation. Combined with the impact of new site openings, this gives adjusted EBITDA of £17.2m, a 10% y-on-y improvement but 12% downgrade against our previous forecast.

BE11:21am

They were buyers and now aren't.

PM11:22am

The thing with Revolution...

11:21 am
PM11:22am

The bars are awful, no?

PM11:22am

Look at this place in Southampton

PM11:22am

Where Scummers are expected to drink

11:22 am
PM11:22am

http://www.revolut...k/bar/southampton/

BE11:22am

Dunno. They serve drinks. That's the minimum qualification for a bar, and they meet it.

PM11:22am

I mean

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Though we may start from different perspectives here. My definition of the best pub in any given area is "the closest one".

undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, so .......

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Heading into the big stuff.

BE11:24am

Hikma.

BE11:24am

Surely we need a stewards here? At least by the Revolution logic.

11:24 am
Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,625, down 75 (-4.41%), High: 1,646, Low: 1,573, Volume: 1.09m
BE11:24am

It slumped! Slumped! ahead of today's warning.

BE11:25am

Okay, yes, it slumped on public information.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

As in, the FDA sending Hikma back to redraft its presentations and re-run its numbers on generic Advair.

BE11:26am

Should we be chasing down the shrewd traders who could see the significance of that info? And if not, why do we need to for a bar operator? I'll stop that theme now.

BE11:26am

So. Q1 weaker than expected.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

(@BornCynic: honestly, I have it 350 words in the paper overnight. It's almost like you're not paying attention.)

BE11:27am

Partly on Advair.

BE11:27am

Also on Hikma finding it increasingly difficult to price gouge in the US.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Here's Numis to summarise.

BE11:28am

Hikma has updated guidance to reflect the anticipated delay for Advair and accelerating price erosion in its US generics business and now expects constant currency sales of $2-$2.1bn in FY17. There is little in the trading statement to arrest the recent weakness: Injectables sales are flat with full year guidance reiterated; Branded sales are expected to be up mid-single digits on CER and Generics guidance has been updated for the delays to Advair, and accelerated price erosion in the US, with profits expected to be up slightly after additional Advair costs has been factored in. Consensus forecasts have come down to our materially since the Complete Response Letter was received on 10th May, but will need to come down further given the increased pressure on the US generics business. The shares trade in line with global peers on our downgraded EPS estimates, with Hikma's strategic value in Injectables and Branded in the Middle East and North Africa potentially offering upside to the shares that have underperformed significantly since the acquisition of Roxane.

BE11:29am

● Moving to the bear case scenario: With anticipated generic margins lower than we’d expected we move to our bear case valuation scenario, adjusted for a longer delay in Advair and factoring in the revised guidance. On this basis we reduce our target price by 15% to 2,000p and reduce our recommendation to add with few catalysts in the coming months. After the recent falls the shares trade on 20x our downgraded EPS forecasts, in line with global peers.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Jefferies.

BE11:30am

If US generic deflation continues it could pose further downside risks: We note our US team's recent proprietary analysis of National Average Drug Acquisition Cost (NADAC) data of drug prices paid by independent pharmacies (HERE) which concluded that US generic deflation remains steep and accelerated in 2H 2016 and into 2017 (10% in first 2m of '17). Whilst we recognise that HIK is increasingly focused on differentiated products, we note a base which we believe is under greater pressure (note a 7.8% 2H '16A adj. margin). If this environment persists, in our view with any delays to new launches we could see further potential downside. Yesterday Express Scripts announced that its Econdisc GPO (which purchases generics for ESRX, Kroger, and SuperValu) is joining the Walgreens Boots Alliance Development (WBAD) GPO which we believe is a significant development in the generic drug supply chain (see US comment HERE); in our view, this could propagate further pricing headwinds and drive sentiment lower.

BE11:31am

And Morgan Stanley as well, since we're here.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Intensifying competition in the US as GPOs consolidate. Yesterday, Express Script announced it will participate in the Walgreens Boots Alliance Development (WBAD) group purchasing organisation (GPO). While timing is estimated at 18-24 months to complete the transition, we believe this is indicative of the intensifying competition, and the consolidating customer base, in the US generics space. Competitors such as Teva and Sandoz have talked about generic price erosion in recent quarters above the mid single digit average.

BE11:31am

(@Pseudonym: they haven't told us, other than to say there's no concern about equivalency.)

undefined
11:32 am
BE11:32am

We can recap Berendsen, since it was mentioned on the right.

PM11:32am

Everyone's upgrading i guess

Berendsen PLC (BRSN:LSE): Last: 1,091, up 45.17 (+4.32%), High: 1,094, Low: 1,050, Volume: 609.33k
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Quite a lot of discussion about whether Elis can sweeten its offer or whether it's done the bear hug because it's at the top of its bid limit.

PM11:34am

hmm

PM11:34am

Really difficult to call that one

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Lex's line is that Elis is stretched: https://www.ft.com...-ac89-b01cc67cfeec

PM11:03am

Hi

PM11:34am

I'd guess they have small headroom to sweeten

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Otherwise, the bear hug approach looks desperate

BE11:35am

Cantor desk note (which we can't quote because desk notes) talking about 550p possible.

BE11:35am

As in the cash component of the offer.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So, Elis net debt's 3.2x. They can go to 4x under the December 2017 covenant.

BE11:36am

At which point it tightens to 3.75x.

BE11:37am

Keeping Berendsen at ~35% of the combined group and keeping to 3.75 would, in theory, give you 550p in cash.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Which, including the new equity, gives you a total price of about £12.50.

BE11:38am

Which -- to reiterate what we said yesterday -- would be extremely reasonable!

BE11:38am

Though Berendsen did set out its defence case yesterday: http://www.berends...-86bd-0a7cad35478b

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Let me spin to the page of that that caught my eye.

PM11:39am

go on

BE11:39am

11:39 am
BE11:40am

That's the company's own bull case!

BE11:40am

More than 100 external management hires within six months or so!

PM11:40am

And quite a few people fired

11:41 am
PM11:41am

That's like panic management

BE11:41am

Yes, exactly. It's a hell of a middle-management churn in a business where customers should stick around for decades.

PM11:41am

Not change

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Here's Stifel, from mid yesterday.

BE11:42am

Over the past nine months we have become increasingly sceptical about BRSN’s direction of travel following leadership change. The restructuring programme announced at the prelims in March did little to reassure us. The company is progressing a high-risk strategy with material execution risks given the scale of the changes being implemented (45% UK managers put on notice/leaving the group, material ramp-up in growth capex, recalibration of the UK business model away from small customers). Money is not the panacea to everything. As such, we see a combination with Elis as an attractive exit route.

BE11:42am

The rationale for the combination is to create a strong pan-European leader in textile and facility services. The top 5 players in Europe include Elis, Berendsen, Rentokil, CWS-Boco and Mewa. With Rentokil and CWS Boco recently agreeing to a joint venture of their workwear businesses there is likely to be little appetite at this juncture for Berendsen. Mewa is a private German company, information is limited but at half the size of BRSN we doubt it can drive market consolidation. We do not rule out private equity making a counter-offer but ascribe a low probability to this.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(The idea for a time, I think, was for Berendsen to buy Rentokil's workwear business as a quick way to bulk up. But for that to happen it'd probably have to stop having profit warnings.)

PM11:44am

(hehehe)

BE11:44am

Also, here's Deutsche.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

We can see the rationale for the transaction and in our view it can be exciting for Elis longer-term if executed well. However, there are several things to consider. Firstly, Elis’ rate of M&A has been fairly aggressive given the recent deal announcements in Brazil and Spain which are taking up management time. Secondly, route-based businesses benefit from adding density in the same geographies while this is a complementary deal instead (overlap only in Germany and Benelux), creating a pan-European laundry provider. We can see material potential for procurement savings and central cost reduction, but we think there is more to prove with the other cost savings. Thirdly, one needs to take into account that Berendsen’s UK business is still in turnaround mode. Elis was at close trading on 18E 17x P/E, 16 EV/EBITA and 4.6% FCF yield.

BE11:45am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

Actually, not Morgan Stanley. It's a good note, but too granular for our purposes.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

I'll only note that, I've suddenly realised, this feels rather like Oberthur's bid for De La Rue.

PM11:47am

(Hedgehog -- Zaoui and Lazard, so yes)

BE11:47am

As in, French company with rather too much debt tries so buy UK peer that's in a bit of a self-created slump as a means to create a scale business.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Oberthur was eventually fended off, though is didn't really benefit DLR shareholders in the short- or even the mid term.

De La Rue PLC (DLAR:LSE): Last: 630.00, down 6.5 (-1.02%), High: 636.00, Low: 629.00, Volume: 15.40k
BE11:49am

Bid was 935p. To remind. And that was 2011.

11:48 am
undefined
PM11:49am

Why the hell is Just Eat up?

PM11:49am

This Competition news is bad news surely?

11:49 am
Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 611.00, up 19 (+3.21%), High: 616.50, Low: 576.50, Volume: 1.65m
BE11:49am

........... certainty? I don't know.

BE11:50am

We have a CMA deadline of November 2. That's certain.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

http://www.investe...1705100706196664E/

BE11:50am

And we have a full investigation in train.

PM11:51am

And Just Didn't Bother To Offer Any Comfort to the CMA

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Which will have, er, got the CMA's backs up, no doubt

BE11:52am

Just spitballing here .... is the best outcome for Just Eat to have the CMA block the deal, but only after six months of disruption to its main competitor?

BE11:52am

I mean, Just Eat doesn't really want Hungry House. It just wants Hungry House dead.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Well...yes

PM11:52am

But that's like mafia finance or something

BE11:53am

It's levering regulation! A good long and complex CMA investigation might, plausibly, be a much cheaper way to stress your competitors than actually buying them.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Anyway, no one in my inbox seems to have commented on the CMA news so that's all you're getting, in terms of insight.

undefined
PM11:54am

Just looking for the Ofcom statement

11:54 am
PM11:55am

Being Ofcom, it's website is rubbish

PM11:55am

Quicker to walk across the road here than use the website for news

BE11:55am

Thumbs up

11:55 am
PM11:56am

Ah, found it

PM11:56am

https://www.ofcom....r-mobile-customers

PM11:56am

Full doc here https://www.ofcom....nications-services

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Surface reading makes it look similar to the broadband switching thing.

PM11:56am

Actualy the actual doc is here, finally chrome-extension://oemmndcbldboiebfnladdacbdfmadadm/https://www.ofcom....tions-services.pdf

PM11:57am

n this consultation, we are proposing a mobile switching process which would remove the need for consumers to speak to their old provider. It would enable consumers to request the unique code they need to switch mobile providers, via text or online, whether they keep their mobile numberor not, rather than having to call their provider.1We are also proposing a requirement to ensure consumers only need to contact their new/gaining provider once in order to porttheir existing number or cancel theirold service. We call this new process the “Auto-Switch” process.1.4We are also proposingthat mobile operators should not be able to chargeconsumers to pay for a notice period once the consumer has switched mobile provider. This will avoid consumers paying for a service they no longer receive after the switch date, and willmake it easier to switch without worrying about notice periods.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Good for consumers, depending on detail. But fairly irrelevant to share prices, I'd have thought.

BE11:58am

Mostly because the UK market's worthless in most models.

PM11:58am

this is true

11:58 am
BE11:58am

And the biggest operator has made no secret that it wants to exit.

BE11:58am

Speaking of, Vodafone downgraded by Barclays this morning.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 221.45, up 1.3 (+0.59%), High: 221.70, Low: 218.70, Volume: 19.31m
11:59 am
BE11:59am

FY17 showed a return to growth in revenues, EBITDA and FCF. Strategic moves (India/NL JVs) have also reduced consolidated leverage. Vodafone has indicated continued momentum for FY18E, with most assets expected to contribute to EBITDA growth. We argue in this report that valuation looks broadly up with events, and that FCF growth beyond FY18 will likely be tempered by rising competitive intensity. Upside potential with Liberty Global remains, but NL trends show a clear divergence in mobile and fixed trends. Secular trends such as 5G and Convergence will also likely keep capex elevated in our view and heighten mobile’s need for fixed.

PM11:59am

(red -- it's clown finance. Period)

BE11:59am

Solid delivery in FY17 – Expect more in FY18 – Competition questions on horizon. Service revenue (ex NL/India) was +1.5% in 4Q17, with Europe mobile remaining a slight negative (even on an underlying basis). Organic EBITDA was +6.3% in 2H, with most assets contributing (UK was key exception). For FY18, management targets 4-8% EBITDA growth (handset leasing is ca2pp boost), with EU roaming a drag. We see Italy/Iliad, UK/BT&EE, Spain/MasMovil and Germany/MVNO wholesale as likely drags into FY19E where we model group EBITDA growth easing to 3% (and Europe flat).

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

5G and Convergence raise structural questions. In 5G – A new dawn (9 Sep 2016), we highlighted that densification/small cells would keep capex elevated, with increasing reliance on fixed infrastructure. Vodafone is increasingly converged, but NL trends (weak mobile vs resilient fixed) raises questions about relative value vs LBTYA. Estimates amended – Lots of moving parts. We trim service revenues slightly (c1%) and upgrade near term EBITDA 2-3% (mostly UK handset accounting). FY20E is unchanged as higher AMAP is offset by lower UK/Italy and Germany MVNO. EPS is broadly unchanged, other than in FY18E where we put India as discontinued vs associate. We also cut NL/India estimates. Medium term FCF is broadly unchanged.

BE12:00pm

Valuation – 225p PT, downgrade to EW. Vodafone trades on 24x Mar 18E P/E, 6.9x EV/EBITDA, and offers a 6.3%/7% divi/equity FCF yield (inc spectrum), vs EU peers on 14.8x, 6.6x, 4.4% and 5.6% respectively. We prefer DT, BT and Orange (all OW).

BE12:01pm

And finally, since we're on Vodafone, there's the always welcome sight in my inbox of an email from Saeed Baradar, Louis Capital.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

He doesn't like Vodafone much.

BE12:01pm

IN MY VIEW, THE CAPEX NUMBERS ARE TOO LOW, DIVIDEND NOT COVERED AND LEVERAGE HIGHER THAN IT SEEMS (reasoning all below) - These will combine to drive under-performance in the stock during 2017 and beyond, in my view. We still will get a good trading week around the results day but the trend will be the same - under-performance.

BE12:02pm

And offers seven reasons. Here are a couple of them.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Why would I want to own a stock with a dividend growth of 2% when DT and Orange are growing dividends at 8-10%pa?

BE12:02pm

Why do I worry that every 1% increase in Capex/Sales for Vodafone reduces FCF by around €500m or 10% and further pressurises a dividend which is barely covered?

BE12:02pm

Why can I not call my broker right now and put all my money in DT rather than Vodafone? Well I know the answer to this one! Firstly I have already sold my house and put all my money into TI and secondly the regulator will probably not look at it favourably!

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

This Saeed chap is just terrific

BE12:03pm

Yep. I genuinely believe he's sold his house to invest in TI, and is now living Partridge style in a Premier Inn off the M25.

undefined
12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

On that note...

PM12:03pm

We are done

PM12:04pm

Actually, I'm done for a month

12:03 pm
PM12:04pm

Seriously

PM12:04pm

One of the perks held over from fleet st days is a thing called sabbaticals

PM12:04pm

We get a month off every four years

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Hm.

PM12:04pm

Ive been here for 11 year but failed to take one yet

PM12:04pm

But I'm doing so now

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Nine years for me, and ditto.

PM12:05pm

We're supposed to do something constructive

PM12:05pm

I've claimed I'm going to learn portuguese (as if) and start a book or something

12:05 pm
PM12:05pm

But really I'm headed for the indian ocean

PM12:06pm

Bryce -- you going to be inviting new guests on here?

BE12:06pm

Might do. Depends.

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Don't try and do it mono!

BE12:06pm

We'll see.

PM12:06pm

Omg smile

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Bye

BE11:34am

Though there is some disagreement.
